metadata.title: Efficient adsorption of radioactive iodide ion from simulated wastewater by nano Cu2O/Cu modified activated carbon

sections.text:
synthesized by a simple and efficient hydrothermal method and used to adsorb iodide ion (I - ) from simulated radioactive wastewater. Nano Cu2O/Cu loaded and uniformly distributed on activated carbon with a diameter of 80 to 100 nm. The composite exhibited excellent adsorption performance, which was primarily attributable to the synergistic effect of nano Cu2O/Cu and activated carbon. Langmuir isotherm and pseudo-second-order kinetic model accurately represented the experimental data of I - adsorption. On the basis of the Langmuir isotherm, the maximum adsorption capacity of I - by nano Cu2O/Cu-C was 41.2 mg/g, which is significantly higher than pure nano Cu2O and activated carbon. The adsorption was affected only slightly by pH and other interfering ions. Additionally, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was used to elucidate the possible adsorption mechanism. This study provides new insight into the fabrication and practical application of high-performance adsorbent in removing radioactive I - from wastewater.
Keywords: Radioactive iodide ion; Adsorption; Activated carbon; Surface modification; Nano Cu2O/Cu

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Radioactive iodine is generated by nuclear fuel reprocessing, medical diagnosis and
treatment, and nuclear accidents, such as those experienced at Chernobyl and Fukushima [1, 2]. Radioactive iodine has different half-lives, ranging from 8.04 days to 1.57×10 7 years, and is mobile in natural water, which will enter aquatic environments, such as oceans, rivers and groundwater, without treatment [3]. Moreover, accumulation of radioactive iodine in the human body can lead to an increase in thyroid cancer, leukemia and metabolic disorders [4]. Generally, aqueous radioactive iodine is present as inorganic iodide (I − , IO3 − ) and organic iodide, and iodide ion (I - ) is the dominant species at low to neutral pH values and positive redox potentials [5-8]. In Japan’s Fukushima accident, radioactive iodine was primarily released in the form of iodide ion
(cesium iodide), and only a small percent was released as other iodine species [9, 10]. Radioactive I - in water cannot be removed by boiling [11]. Emergency treatment of radioactive I - remains an important challenge. Thus, investigating the removal of radioactive I - from water has been a central focus in water pollution control.
Various methods have been examined for the treatment of water contaminated by radioactive
I - , such as adsorption [12-14], ion exchange [15, 16], membrane separation [17] and precipitation [18]. Notably, adsorption has been proven to be a clean and efficient method for the treatment and purification of wastewater, and the development of reliable adsorbents is favored in this area. In the case of adsorbents for removing radioactive I - , activated carbon has been studied widely [5, 19-22]. However, the interaction between I - and activated carbon is that of physical adsorption, resulting in a relatively low efficacy of radioactive I - removal. For instance, Lettinga et al. [22] reported that activated carbon showed a low removal percentage of 131 I - . The study of Kosaka et al. [20] indicated that the removal percentages of 131 I - in river and pond waters by 25 mg/L of powdered activated carbon were 36% and 41%, respectively. Without question, adsorbents with high adsorption ability are in great demand. To this end, surface modifications of activated carbon could be used to enhance its adsorption capacity for radioactive I - .
Iodide ion is known to concentrate around copper deposits [23]. Metal-modified activated
carbon was reported to have great advantages because of its strong interaction and because it does not introduce any other anions into water that would lead to secondary pollution [24]. In recent years, nano-scale cuprous oxide (Cu2O) has attracted increasing attention in various fields including catalysis [25], semiconductor [26] and environmental remediation [27], to name a few. Further, Cu2O itself could serve to adsorb I - from wastewater [23, 28]. Cuprous ion (Cu + ) appears to be promising for trapping I - because of the strong affinity between Cu + and I - . However, Cu2O showed slow adsorption activity in aqueous solution under the condition of air. Compared with the traditional scale, nano-scale Cu2O material can be more stable, possess faster reaction rates and much higher efficiencies for contaminated water treatment because of their high surface areas and increased number of active sites. Immobilization of nano-scaled Cu2O on activated carbon supports can prevent the nanoparticles from self-aggregating to take advantage of their functionalities for convenient separation. Moreover, synergistic effects of the adsorption ability of activated carbon and nano-scaled Cu2O could provide new insights into the fabrication of high-performance adsorbents for I - in many practical applications.
In the present study, a novel nano Cu2O/Cu modified activated carbon composite (nano
Cu2O/Cu-C) adsorbent was synthesized by a simple one-step hydrothermal method using poly ethylenimine (PEI) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O as the primary materials. Activated carbon acted as the
substrate to load the Cu2O nanoparticles, which could effectively prevent nanoparticles aggregation. Subsequently, the as-prepared nano Cu2O/Cu-C was used to remove I - from simulated radioactive wastewater. To the best of our knowledge, studies on the method to synthesize nano Cu2O/Cu-C, as well as the application of such a composite in the removal of I - from simulated radioactive wastewater, have rarely been reported. The main objectives of this study are: (1) to prepare and characterize nano Cu2O/Cu-C for adsorption of radioactive I - from simulated wastewater; (2) to study the adsorption properties of nano Cu2O/Cu-C and compare them with those of nano Cu2O and activated carbon; and (3) to discuss the adsorption mechanism for adsorption of I - . Overall, our work suggests that introducing nano Cu2O/Cu into activated carbon can be a feasible approach to adsorb radioactive I - from wastewater.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and reagents
sections.text:
Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (purity>99%) and poly ethylenimine (PEI, MW 1800, purity>99%) were
purchased from Maclin Corporation (China), potassium iodide (KI) was purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (China) and potassium chloride (KCl) and potassium sulfate (K2SO4) were purchased from Jiangtian Chemical Technology Ltd. (Tianjin, China). KI and deionized water were used to prepare an iodide stock solution for the adsorption experiments. Stable iodide ( 127 I - ) was used as the surrogate for radioactive iodide in this study, which could provide similar information concerning the removal of radioactive I - [19, 29, 30]. Activated carbon in experiments is a commercially available coconut shell activated carbon, washed several times with deionized water before use. The grain size of the activated carbon was 150–180 μm with a specific area of 1220 m 2 /g, and the iodine value was >1000 mg/g. Nano Cu2O in the comparison experiment was purchased from Zhongke Leiming Science and Technology Ltd. (China).
All of the aqueous solutions were prepared using analytical-grade reagents and used without
further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of the nano Cu2O/Cu-C composite
sections.text:
The nano Cu2O/Cu-C composite was labeled as a mass ratio of cupric ion (Cu 2+ ) to activated
carbon. Taking the 1:5 nano Cu2O/Cu-C as an example, its fabrication is described as follows. Briefly, 1.06 g of PEI and 1.52 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O that contains Cu 2+ of 0.400 g were dissolved in 100 mL of Milli-Q water and stirred to form a homogeneous dispersion. Then, 2.00 g of the activated carbon was submerged in this blue solution and stirred for Cu 2+ adsorption. The mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (150 mL capacity), and the autoclave was heated to
60 °C for several minutes to remove the traces of oxygen, then was sealed and heated at 220 °C for 3 h. After natural cooling, the sample was washed four times with deionized water and dried at 60 °C under vacuum to obtain red-brown precipitates. Through the same process, a series of 1:10, 1:3, 1:2, 1:1.5 and 1:1 nano Cu2O/Cu-C composites were prepared.

sections.heading: 2.3. Analytical methods and characterization
sections.text:
The I - concentration was determined by a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Model TU-1810,
China), using a Chinese standard examination method for drinking water [31]. Additional details are presented in the Supplementary data S1. The Cu 2+ in the effluent water was measured using an X Series inductively coupled plasma mass spectrophotometer (Thermo Electro Corporation, USA). The morphology and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) of the as-synthesized nano Cu2O/Cu-C were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, HITACHI S-4800, Japan). Transmission electron microscopy was performed with a JEM-1200EX (TEM, Japan) at an accelerating voltage of 120 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-alpha, England) was employed to study the chemical state changes of the prepared adsorbent before and after I - adsorption. Zeta potentials of nano Cu2O/Cu-C/water at different pH values (3.0, 5.0, 7.0, 9.0 and 11.0) were measured on a Malvern Zetasizer Nano ZS (England) three times for a single sample to provide an average reading.

sections.heading: 2.4. Adsorbent stability
sections.text:
Chemical stability was studied in terms of the dissolvability of nano Cu2O/Cu-C after stirring
for 2 h and immersing for 24 h, respectively, in deionized water under different pH. The dissolved
percentage was tested by adding 0.200 g (m1) of the as-synthesized nano Cu2O/Cu-C to be
immersed in 200 mL of deionized water, then adjust pH in the range of 5.0-9.0. After stirring for 2
h and immersing for 24 h, respectively, solid phase was separated from liquid phase, then dried
under vacuum and weighted (m2). The dissolved percentage (%dissolved) was calculated as
follow:

sections.heading: 2.5. Batch adsorption procedure
sections.text:
All solutions were prepared using deionized water, and all experiments were conducted in 50
mL centrifugal tubes. The batch adsorption experiments were performed on a shaker (HT 2202C, China) with a shaking speed of 200 rpm. Briefly, 40.0 mg of adsorbents were added to 40.0 mL of freshly prepared solution, except those that were used to investigate the effect of adsorbent dosage.
Negligible volumes of 0.10 mol/L HCl or NaOH solutions were added to adjust the pH. All experiments were conducted at a pH value of 7.0, except those that investigated the effect of pH. Moreover, the initial I - concentrations in all of the experiments were 2.00 mg/L except those related to the adsorption isotherms. The system was then shaken at 298 K for approximately 2 h to achieve adsorption equilibrium. Adsorption kinetic experiments were conducted by shaking 1.0 g/L of nano Cu2O/Cu-C with a volume of 40.0 mL of I - solution at the initial concentration of 2.00 mg/L, and sampled at time intervals of 10, 20, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min. The effect of adsorbent dosage on I - adsorption was studied at different adsorbent concentrations in the range of 0.25-8.0 g/L at the initial I - concentration of 2.00 mg/L. Adsorption isotherm studies were performed at 298 K by varying I - initial concentration from 1.00 to 30.0 mg/L. The impact of temperature of 288, 298 and 308 K on I - adsorption was also investigated. The effects of ionic strength on adsorption ability of nano Cu2O/Cu-C were carried out using Cl - and SO4 2 as the interfering ions. After equilibrium, the suspension was filtrated through a 0.22 μm membrane (Shanghai mixed cellulose ester. China) to separate the solid and liquid phases.
The amount of I - adsorbed on the adsorbent, qe (mg/g), was calculated using Eq.(2):

In addition, the control adsorption-free experiment indicated that the effect of the centrifugal tube wall on the uptake of I - could be neglected. Solutions with interfering ions were prepared by dissolving kali salts of Cl - and SO4 2- .

sections.heading: 3.1. Formation mechanism of nano Cu2O/Cu-C
sections.text:
The synthesis of the nano Cu2O/Cu-C composites were studied by changing the ratio of PEI
to Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and the hydrothermal reaction time. The ratio was determined by the molar ratio of nitrogen in PEI to Cu 2+
in Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. In this case, the ratio is 4:1, which is benefit
for nano Cu2O formation and its immobilization on activated carbon. The hydrothermal reaction
time for the synthesis is another significant factor to consider. In this study, the nano Cu2O/Cu-C composites were prepared by hydrothermal treatment at 220 °C with changing reaction times of 1, 3, 5, 7 and 12 h. Table 1 shows that I - removal efficiency was increased when hydrothermal time was controlled in 3 h, and reached highest at 3 h. While prolonging the hydrothermal time from 3 to 7 h and 12 h gradually reduced the adsorption performance. Thus, the hydrothermal reaction time was controlled with the optimal 3 h to synthesize the composite.
Table 1 Effect of hydrothermal time on the synthesis and adsorption performance of nano Cu2O/Cu-C composite.
Hydrothermal time (h) 1 3 5 7 12
Removal efficiency (%) 94.4 95.7 88.5 84.3 83.5
In the synthesized procedure, PEI can strongly coordinate with Cu 2+ because of its rich
secondary amine groups, and can also be robustly adsorbed onto various substrates [27, 32]. In this study, activated carbon was used as the substrate. When activated carbon was immersed in the mixed solution of PEI and Cu 2+ at room temperature, the concentration of Cu 2+ and PEI around the activated carbon surface will be much higher than that in the bulk solution. Moreover, PEI is a strong reducing agent at high temperature, which can reduce Cu 2+ to Cu + for further reacting with OH − to form Cu2O or to metallic copper (Cu) under hydrothermal treatment [33]. A relatively lower ratio of PEI to Cu 2+
is favorable for Cu2O formation on activated carbon, but it is not ideal
for the adsorption of PEI on activated carbon to stabilize nano Cu2O/Cu; whereas a higher ratio of PEI to Cu 2+ is beneficial to form metallic Cu [27]. In addition to the reduction ability of PEI at high temperature, Cu 2+ could also be reduced by activated carbon [34]. Thus, the hydrothermal reaction time must be carefully controlled. The reason for this can be understood in terms of reducing Cu2O to metal Cu with increasing hydrothermal treatment time [34], which will cause more metal Cu to load on the carbon and occupy active sites.
The synthetic route and reaction process of the nano Cu2O/Cu-C composite are presented in
Scheme 1.
Scheme 1. Synthesis of the nano Cu2O/Cu-C composite.

sections.heading: 3.2. Characterizations of nano Cu2O/Cu-C composite
sections.text:
The general morphologies of commercial nano Cu2O and the synthesized nano Cu2O/Cu-C
composite characterized by SEM and TEM are shown Fig. 1. Fig. 1A shows the SEM image of the nano Cu2O and reveals that the pure nano Cu2O self-aggregates into large clusters. For a clear observation of the nano Cu2O/Cu on activated carbon, the general morphology of the 1:1.5 nano Cu2O/Cu-C is shown in Figs. 1B, C and D. As seen in Fig. 1B, the image suggests that the nano Cu2O/Cu loaded on the surface of carbon, and the wrinkles that appear on the composite suggest its is activated carbon. Because the amount of nano Cu2O/Cu was not enough to coat the entire activated carbon surface, some areas cannot be wrapped by the nano Cu2O/Cu particles. On the carbon surface loaded with nano Cu2O/Cu particles, the nano Cu2O/Cu distributed relatively uniformly with little aggregation. The 100 K SEM image (Fig. 1C) and the TEM image (Fig. 1D) reveal that the approximate size of the nano Cu2O/Cu on carbon is 80–100 nm.
The EDS analysis of nano Cu2O/Cu-C in Fig. S1A (Supplementary Material) shows that the
composite consists of C, O and Cu. The elemental mapping of nano Cu2O/Cu-C is given in Fig. S1. Figs. S1B, C and D indicate the well-dispersed C, Cu and O elements on the surface of nano Cu2O/Cu-C. Further, Fig. 2A illustrates the XPS survey spectra of nano Cu2O/Cu-C, which also exhibits the presence of C, O and Cu. The peak positions of Cu 2p are shown in Fig. 2B. Two peaks at binding energies of 932.8 and 952.5 eV could be ascribed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 from Cu2O, respectively [35]. The peaks at 934.4, 935.1, 941.9, 944.8 and 954.5 eV indicated that Cu 2+ and CuO on the composite surface [35, 36]. It is difficult to distinguish between copper (0) and copper (I) because the chemical shifts are very small [23].

SEM, TEM, EDS and XPS measurements confirmed that nano Cu2O/Cu successfully loaded
on the activated carbon.

sections.heading: 3.3. Adsorption behavior of iodide ion
sections.text:
3.3.1. Optimization of the Cu 2+ and activated carbon ratio
The removal efficiencies of I - by nano Cu2O/Cu-C with different mass ratios of Cu 2+ to
activated carbon are shown in Fig. 3. As observed, when the mass ratio of Cu 2+ to activated carbon increased from 1:10 to 1:3, the removal efficiency increased, suggesting that nano Cu2O/Cu is the active component in the composite. However, as the mass ratio continued to increase to 1:1, the I - removal efficiency by nano Cu2O/Cu-C showed a decreasing trend. The reason for this behavior could be that the increased ratio of nano Cu2O/Cu loaded on the carbon occupied the active sites required for I - adsorption. The amount of I - adsorbed by the 1:5 and 1:3 nano Cu2O/Cu-C were slightly higher than those of the 1:10, 1:2, 1:1.5 and 1:1 nano Cu2O/Cu-C. Considering that the 1:5 nano Cu2O/Cu-C would reduce the amount of primary materials required for synthesis and its excellent adsorption ability, this composite was chosen for the subsequent adsorption experiments.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Effect of contact time and adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the removal efficiency of I - with contact time. To determine the equilibrium time
of adsorption, the adsorbents were added into 2.00 mg/L I - solution followed by sampling at time intervals of 10, 20, 30, 60, 90 and 120 min. The results suggest that the three adsorbents reacted rapidly with I - within 10 min. The extremely high increasing trend of removal efficiency during the first 10 min occurred because of the abundance of adsorbates and active sites on the adsorbents, and a large number of I - from bulk solution transported easily to the adsorbent active sites. With increased contact time, the occupation of the active sites and the decrease of the I - concentration became more evident, and the removal efficiency increased slowly and became constant after 90–120 min. Therefore, it can be considered that 2 h is sufficient to reach equilibrium in the
following adsorption experiments.

To determine the rate-controlling step in the adsorption process of I - on nano Cu2O/Cu-C,
pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order kinetic models were used to analyze the kinetic data, which can be expressed as Eqs. (4) and (5), respectively:
e e 1log( ) logtq q q k t

where qt (mg/g) is amount of I - adsorbed on the adsorbents at time t, k1 and k2 (1/min and g/mg/min) are the adsorption rate constants, and t (min) is the adsorption time.
Pseudo-first and second-order plots are shown in Fig. S2 in Supplementary Material, and the
corresponding qe values are shown in Table S1. The calculated qe (2.00 mg/g) from the pseudo-second-order model is consistent with the experimental data (1.91 mg/g); in contrast, the qe calculated from the pseudo-first-order model failed to agree with the experimental data. Therefore, the pseudo-second-order model better describes the I - adsorption kinetics of nano Cu2O/Cu-C. According to a previous study [37], the pseudo-second-order model is based on the assumption that the rate-limiting step may be chemisorption or chemical sorption involving valence forces through sharing or exchanging electrons between the adsorbent and the adsorbate. Thus, it can be inferred that a chemical process controls the I - adsorption process on nano Cu2O/Cu-C.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Effect of adsorbent dosage on the removal efficiency of iodide ion
sections.text:
Adsorbent dosages of 0.25, 0.50, 1.0, 2.0, 4.0 and 8.0 g/L were used to
investigate the I - removal efficiency. As shown in Fig. 5, the I - removal efficiency increased with the amount of added adsorbent, which may well be caused by the increased number of active sites
available for I - with the increased amount of adsorbent. With the same dose of 1.0 g/L for nano Cu2O, activated carbon and nano Cu2O/Cu-C, 38.2%, 68.6% and 95.7% of I - were adsorbed, respectively. Notably, for nano Cu2O/Cu-C, the I - removal efficiency did not increase with increasing dosage when it increased to 1.0 g/L. Thus, 1.0 g/L was sufficient to achieve high efficiency of the adsorption of I - for nano Cu2O/Cu-C and was chosen as the optimal dosage in the following adsorption experiments.

sections.heading: 3.3.4. Effect of initial concentration and adsorption isotherm
sections.text:
To determine the adsorption isotherms, the initial I - concentrations were set from 1.00 to 30.0
mg/L. The adsorption isotherms of I - on nano Cu2O, activated carbon and nano Cu2O/Cu-C are shown in Fig. 6. Clearly, the amounts of I - adsorbed on the three adsorbents increased with increasing initial concentration within the same adsorbent dosage (1.0 g/L). The adsorption isotherms of I - on the adsorbents were simulated using the Langmuir model, whereby its linear form can be described by Eq.(6):
e m e m
1 1 1 1
Lq K q C q   
(6)
where KL (L/mg) is the Langmuir adsorption coefficient and qm (mg/g) is maximum adsorption capacity. Plots of 1/qe versus 1/Ce of I - for nano Cu2O, activated carbon and nano Cu2O/Cu-C are shown in the insets of images Figs. 6A, B and C. The values of R 2 , qm and KL were obtained from the linear correlation, slope and intercept of each plot, respectively. More specific information is listed in Table S2 in Supplementary Material. Table S2 shows that the adsorption isotherms could be fitted with high R 2 . In addition, fitting with the Langmuir adsorption isotherm showed higher R 2 values than that with Freundlich adsorption isotherm, indicating better fitting with the Langmuir adsorption isotherm. From the Langmuir model, the maximum adsorption capacities (qm) of nano Cu2O, activated carbon and nano Cu2O/Cu-C were determined to be 3.23, 5.26 and 41.2
mg/g, respectively.
The dimensionless coefficient RL was used to describe the adsorption intensity of the
adsorbents, and the formula for RL is calculated by Eq. (7) [38]:
nano Cu2O/Cu-C (pH=7.0, T=298 K, adsorbent dose= 1.0 g/L).

sections.heading: 3.3.5. Effect of temperature and adsorption thermodynamics
sections.text:
The influence of temperature of I - adsorption on nano Cu2O/Cu-C was examined at
temperatures of 288, 298 and 308 K. Plots of 1/qe versus 1/Ce of I - on the composite at these three
temperatures are shown in Fig. 7. As shown in Fig. 7 and calculated by the Langmuir models, the maximum adsorption capacity (qm) of nano Cu2O/Cu-C at temperatures of 288, 298 and 308 K were determined to be 55.3, 41.2 and 34.6 mg/g, respectively. Temperature had a little effect on the adsorption, and the maximum adsorption capacity decreased slightly when the temperature changed from 288 to 308 K, suggesting that the adsorption process was exothermic.

TheG 0 values were calculated to be -5.04, -4.34 and -4.05 kJ/mol at temperatures of 288, 298 and 308 K, respectively. The negative values of G0 indicate that the adsorption was spontaneous, and the H0 value of -19.3 kJ/mol indicates that the adsorption was an exothermic.
A comparison of the I - adsorption ability of nano Cu2O/Cu-C with adsorbents reported in
other literature is shown in Table 2. The results show that the adsorbent prepared in this study is suitable for I - adsorption because of its shorter equilibrium time, lower adsorbent dosage and high maximum adsorption capacity at lower I - concentration.

sections.heading: 3.3.6. Effect of pH on the removal efficiency of iodide ion
sections.text:
properties of the adsorbent. The effect of pH for I - adsorption on three adsorbents is shown in Fig. 8A. As observed, the adsorption performance of nano Cu2O and activated carbon were highly dependent on the solution pH. With an increase of pH, the removal efficiency of I - showed a decreasing trend. However, for nano Cu2O/Cu-C, the optimal range of pH was wide and slightly dependent on the solution pH. For instance, high adsorption abilities were exhibited at pH values from 3.0 to 9.0. Notably, the removal efficiency was achieved 82.7% at pH ~11.0.

Fig. 8. Effect of pH on the removal efficiency against different pH values and pH in effluent after nano Cu2O/Cu-C adsorption (T=298 K, C0(I -) =2.00 mg/L, adsorbents dose=1.0 g/L).
For nano Cu2O, Cu2O was partially dissolved at lower pH and Cu + species were released into
solution. In the presence of I - , CuI formed on the adsorbent surface. At intermediate pH values (pH﹤7.5), and in addition to CuI formed on nano Cu2O, nano Cu2O contains surface hydroxyl groups (OH - ) that were able to react with solution species, which contributed to I - adsorption via surface complexes. At high pH values, nano Cu2O was oxidized to Cu(OH)2 or CuO, which did not exhibit affinity for I - and the uptake of I - was predicted to be negligible [28].
For activated carbon, at lower pH, large number of H + ions resulted in the protonation of the
adsorbent surface, which promoted the interaction between H + and I - ions through electrostatic interaction, and therefore the adsorption of I - by activated carbon was high. As the pH increased, the adsorbent surface became negatively charged with OH - groups, which reduced the interaction between the adsorbent surface and the negatively charged I - [12].
For nano Cu2O/Cu-C, because of the synergistic effect of nano Cu2O and activated carbon,
the optimal pH range was wide and exhibited high adsorption ability. Supplementary Fig. S3 shows the zeta potentials of nano Cu2O/Cu-C with different pH values. As we can see, the pHzpc occurred around pH 10.2. The surface of nano Cu2O/Cu-C was positive at the pH range of 3.0–9.0 (pH<pHzpc) and the positive zeta potential values slightly decreased as the pH increased. Although the surface charge changed with increasing pH, the adsorption ability was found to be insensitive to initial solution pH in a range of 3.0–9.0, showing that in this pH range, the electrostatic interactions between I - and nano Cu2O/Cu-C did not contribute a significant effect to the adsorption reaction in general. Additionally, the pH changed before and after adsorption. As seen in Fig. 8B, the pH at initial values of 3.0 and 5.0 changed to 4.8 and 6.6 after adsorption. This increase in pH demonstrates an exchange of I - and surface OH - on nano Cu2O/Cu-C and the release of OH - to water. As the pH increased to 9.0, OH - could also be adsorbed on the adsorbent surface in the solution with low I - concentration, resulting in a decrease of the pH after adsorption. Compared with that before adsorption, the pH changed little after adsorption for high pH (~11.0).
The reason for this could be because the abundant number of negatively charged OH - species act as competitive ions to reduce the interaction between nano Cu2O/Cu-C and I - , leading the removal efficiency in alkaline solution that was slightly lower than that in acidic and neutral solutions.
In addition, the Cu 2+ concentrations in the effluent after adsorption at different pH values
were studied (Fig. 9). At initial pH values of 3.0, 5.0, 7.0, 9.0 and 11.0, the Cu 2+ concentrations in the effluent were 10.5, 2.06, 1.64, 1.21 and 0.09 mg/L, respectively. The Cu 2+ concentration in the effluent at pH 3.0 was the highest and gradually decreased with pH from 3.0 to 11.0. These results correspond with a mechanism that involves nano Cu2O to be partially dissolved and the release of Cu + species in acidic solution. In the neutral and alkaline solutions, the Cu 2+ concentration in the effluent were below the standard (2.00 mg/L) in the guidelines for drinking-water quality [49], indicating no secondary pollution was produced.

sections.heading: 3.3.7. Effect of ionic strength on the removal efficiency of iodide ion
sections.text:
Inorganic salts are commonly present in water and result in a high ionic strength, which
compete with I - for the adsorption active sites on the adsorbent. Therefore, a potential adsorbent should have an excellent resistance to interfering ions. The effect of ionic strength on the adsorption of nano Cu2O, activated carbon and nano Cu2O/Cu-C were investigated by using Cl - and SO4 2- at concentrations of 20.0 and 200 mg/L. As seen in Fig. 10, when the Cl - strength was set at 20.0 mg/L, the removal efficiency decreased from 38.2%, 68.6% and 95.7% to 34.1%, 54.7% and 94.2% for the three adsorbents, respectively. Clearly, essentially no effect on the adsorption ability of nano Cu2O/Cu-C was observed. At higher ionic strength, the removal efficiency decreased to 20.9%, 22.1% and 81.7% for nano Cu2O, activated carbon and nano Cu2O/Cu-C, respectively, when the Cl - strength was set at 200 mg/L. Similarly, when the SO4 2-
strength was set at 20.0 mg/L, the removal efficiency decreased to 34.3%, 54.1% and 87.8% for nano Cu2O, activated carbon and nano Cu2O/Cu-C, respectively, and the removal efficiency decreased to 28.3%, 40.3% and 78.1% for these adsorbents when the SO4 2- strength increased to 200 mg/L. Compared with nano Cu2O and activated carbon, adsorption by nano Cu2O/Cu-C exhibited excellent resistance to interfering ions. With lower ion strength, adsorption was not very dependent on the ion strength, which implies that inner-sphere surface complexation played an important role in the adsorption process of I - on nano Cu2O/Cu-C [50].

sections.heading: 3.3.8. Adsorbent stability
sections.text:
After stirring for 2 h and immersing for 24 h, respectively, under different pH conditions, it is
noted in Table S3 that nano Cu2O/Cu-C was stable with the dissolved percentages of less than
6.0% under slightly acidic to alkaline conditions (pH~5.0-9.0). Furthermore, adsorbent stability was studied by the removal efficiency of I - . As can be seen from Table S3, after stirring for 2 h and immersing for 24 h, respectively, in deionized water under pH values of 5.0-9.0, high I - removal
efficiencies of nano Cu2O/Cu-C were also exhibited. Thus, the synthesized adsorbent was
reasonably stable for practical adsorption applications.

sections.heading: 3.4. Adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
Following these adsorption results, it can be emphasized that nano Cu2O/Cu-C could
effectively remove I - from aqueous solution. Two mechanisms could lead to I - uptake by nano Cu2O/Cu-C at pH ~7.0: (i) adsorption by surface complexes caused by an array of adsorption active sites on the adsorbent; and (ii) I - precipitated as CuI. To verify the adsorption reaction mechanism, XPS spectra were obtained to detect changes of nano Cu2O/Cu-C before and after
adsorption (Fig. 11).
XPS deconvolution of the survey and I 3d spectrum of nano Cu2O/Cu-C after 30.0 mg/L (for

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
A novel and effective nano Cu2O/Cu-C composite adsorbent was firstly synthesized by a
simple one-step hydrothermal method. SEM, TEM, EDS and XPS analyses showed that 80–100 nm nano Cu2O/Cu particles loaded on the surface of activated carbon. The prepared nano
Cu2O/Cu-C composite showed high adsorption capacity for I - in aqueous solution. Kinetics study indicated that the adsorption followed a pseudo-second-order model and the Langmuir model was in good agreement with the experimental adsorption isotherm. The Langmuir isotherm model indicated that the maximum adsorption capacity was 41.2 mg/g under neutral conditions. Additionally, the composite exhibited excellent resistance to interfering ions with lower ion strength and excellent adsorption ability under a wide pH range. The relatively high adsorption efficiency of nano Cu2O/Cu-C is attributed to the synergistic effect of nano Cu2O and activated carbon. The adsorption mechanism involves complexation and precipitation on the composite. Overall, it is clear that the high adsorption ability of the synthesized adsorbent is a potentially attractive material for the efficient removal of radioactive I - from wastewater.

Nano Cu2O/Cu-carbon composite was firstly synthesized to adsorb I - from wastewater.
Instrumental analyses indicate the 80-100 nm nano Cu2O/Cu loaded on activated carbon. I - adsorption by the nano Cu2O/Cu-carbon composite up to 41.2 mg/g was observed. Wide pH range, excellent interfering ions resistance of I - adsorption were obtained.
Adsorption mechanism involves complexation and precipitation on the composite.

referenceMentions.context: Radioactive iodine is generated by nuclear fuel reprocessing, medical diagnosis and treatment, and nuclear accidents, such as those experienced at Chernobyl and Fukushima [1, 2].
Radioactive iodine is generated by nuclear fuel reprocessing, medical diagnosis and treatment, and nuclear accidents, such as those experienced at Chernobyl and Fukushima [1, 2].
57×10 7 years, and is mobile in natural water, which will enter aquatic environments, such as oceans, rivers and groundwater, without treatment [3].
Moreover, accumulation of radioactive iodine in the human body can lead to an increase in thyroid cancer, leukemia and metabolic disorders [4].

Generally, aqueous radioactive iodine is present as inorganic iodide (I − , IO3 − ) and organic iodide, and iodide ion (I ) is the dominant species at low to neutral pH values and positive redox potentials [5-8].

Generally, aqueous radioactive iodine is present as inorganic iodide (I − , IO3 − ) and organic iodide, and iodide ion (I ) is the dominant species at low to neutral pH values and positive redox potentials [5-8].

Generally, aqueous radioactive iodine is present as inorganic iodide (I − , IO3 − ) and organic iodide, and iodide ion (I ) is the dominant species at low to neutral pH values and positive redox potentials [5-8].

Generally, aqueous radioactive iodine is present as inorganic iodide (I − , IO3 − ) and organic iodide, and iodide ion (I ) is the dominant species at low to neutral pH values and positive redox potentials [5-8].
2 (cesium iodide), and only a small percent was released as other iodine species [9, 10].
2 (cesium iodide), and only a small percent was released as other iodine species [9, 10].
Radioactive I in water cannot be removed by boiling [11].
Various methods have been examined for the treatment of water contaminated by radioactive I , such as adsorption [12-14], ion exchange [15, 16], membrane separation [17] and precipitation [18].

In the synthesized procedure, PEI can strongly coordinate with Cu 2+ because of its rich secondary amine groups, and can also be robustly adsorbed onto various substrates [27, 32].
Moreover, PEI is a strong reducing agent at high temperature, which can reduce Cu 2+ to Cu + for further reacting with OH − to form Cu2O or to metallic copper (Cu) under hydrothermal treatment [33].

A relatively lower ratio of PEI to Cu 2+ is favorable for Cu2O formation on activated carbon, but it is not ideal for the adsorption of PEI on activated carbon to stabilize nano Cu2O/Cu; whereas a higher ratio of PEI to Cu 2+ is beneficial to form metallic Cu [27].
In addition to the reduction ability of PEI at high temperature, Cu 2+ could also be reduced by activated carbon [34].

The reason for this can be understood in terms of reducing Cu2O to metal Cu with increasing hydrothermal treatment time [34], which will cause more metal Cu to load on the carbon and occupy active sites.

metadata.abstractText: Nano Cu2O/Cu modified activated carbon composite (nano Cu2O/Cu-C) was firstly synthesized by a simple and efficient hydrothermal method and used to adsorb iodide ion (I ) from simulated radioactive wastewater. Nano Cu2O/Cu loaded and uniformly distributed on activated carbon with a diameter of 80 to 100 nm. The composite exhibited excellent adsorption performance, which was primarily attributable to the synergistic effect of nano Cu2O/Cu and activated carbon. Langmuir isotherm and pseudo-second-order kinetic model accurately represented the experimental data of I adsorption. On the basis of the Langmuir isotherm, the maximum adsorption capacity of I by nano Cu2O/Cu-C was 41.2 mg/g, which is significantly higher than pure nano Cu2O and activated carbon. The adsorption was affected only slightly by pH and other interfering ions. Additionally, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was used to elucidate the possible adsorption mechanism. This study provides new insight into the fabrication and practical application of high-performance adsorbent in removing radioactive I from wastewater.
